discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Maker Accessing Mortgage loans Through Bacon Protocol

content.content: Overview MakerDAO has implemented the DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) which has the ability to distribute DAI loans to real world home owners through the Bacon protocol. Utilizing D3M, DAI lending capital would be deposited into a newly created Bacon DAI pool that limits lending participation to MakerDAO only. BaconDAO will oversee the pool and would select home loans based on a prescribed mandate (FICO score, LTV etc.) from the MakerDAO community.  Signal Request Bacon protocol is signaling to onboard a D3M for the creation of a Bacon DAI pool.  Pros   Single onboarding procedure that can scale both the amount of capital used and the number of home loans over time   Broad potential distribution of DAI to home owners in the US   Higher risk adjusted yields across a diversified set of home loans   Maker selects the underwriting criteria to use, allowing for investing in loans that are highly aligned with Maker’s vision of funding sustainability initiatives   Bacon will develop and maintain the D3M integration in line with the CES enablement strategy   Governance has direct control over DAI supply that is added to Bacon through the Debt Ceiling    Cons  Smart contract risk   Risk Mitigation   The whitelisting of addresses with deposit functionality reduces exploit risk (Maker would be the only liquidity provider)   Credit Risk assessment of borrowers is performed by loan originators using the industry-standard FICO-score.    Effect In the event this signal is successful, Bacon will prioritize the implementation of a DAI Bacon pool D3M, and will consult with the Maker team regularly. After this, with all details fleshed out, the proposal will move to a Maker community vote.    Should Maker Onboard a Bacon D3M?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters      Next Steps Added by @LongForWisdom - 2022-05-08 Off-chain poll will end on 2022-05-19T00:00:00Z. If it is successful at that time, it will move on-chain in the ‘Investigation Implementation’ format.
content.GPT-summary: The post is an explanation of a proposal by MakerDAO to implement the DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) to distribute DAI loans to homeowners through the Bacon protocol. The post also includes a signal request for MakerDAO to onboard a D3M for the creation of a Bacon DAI pool. The post lists the pros and cons of the proposal and includes a poll for the Maker community to vote on whether to onboard the Bacon D3M. The post also includes information on the next steps if the poll is successful.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
3rd party or author is advertising proposal

content.content: This sounds very interesting. Can you expand more about the smart contract risk ?

Thanks for posting this, @abdalla. It would be great to get some more information about the Bacon Protocol and some specifics about your proposal (the details above are quite sparse). For instance:   What debt ceiling do you propose for the D3M?   What is the background of Bacon Protocol/Bacon DAO? How many loans has the protocol provided, to how many borrowers, and what average rate? What is the total value of those loans?   Could you describe the general profile of your protocol’s borrowers to date? How many have defaulted?   What are the capital or illiquidity risks with Bacon loans? To what extent can these be mitigated?   What would happen if a borrower defaults on a loan? It would be great if you could walk through your procedure and its implications for Maker.   A link to D3M documentation is here if helpful: DAI Direct Deposit - Maker Operational Manual.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: So going into this I assumed (and maybe others had as well) Bacon was proposing a “crypto-mortgage” protocol but it is not. A “crypto-mortgage” is a loan collateralized against both a residential property and a borrower’s crypto assets. Instead, Bacon is originating Fannie/Freddie conforming mortgages and passing through the interest payments to bHome holders. It also incentivizes bHome holders via Bacon emissions. I guess my immediate concerns/questions are around Bacon’s edge in underwriting/production of a well-understood and crowded asset class. How does Bacon compete with these scaled operators? Is it speed-to-close as is so often the value prop with RE lending upstarts?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Hi Matt, nice to meet you.  I am the CEO and co-founder of LoanSnap and we created the Bacon Protocol.  Thanks for your interest in our project and here are answers to your questions  What debt ceiling do you propose for the D3M? We are proposing $10M and are open to feedback What is the background of Bacon Protocol/Bacon DAO? The protocol was designed and developed by LoanSnap Holdings Inc  It was launched in Sept of 2021  The project has been under development for about 3yrs. How many loans has the protocol provided, to how many borrowers, and what average rate? What is the total value of those loans?    This information is kept real time on chain but can also be accessed by viewing www.baconcoin.com  We believe a key component of our stablecoin is transparency so anyone at any time can determine borrowers, rate and total value of the loans        Could you describe the general profile of your protocol’s borrowers to date? How many have defaulted? The loans backing bHOME (the stablecoin) are underwritten to fannie mae guidelines This ensures we can sell the loans to Fannie Mae directly to their cash window https://selling-guide.fanniemae.com/  What are the capital or illiquidity risks with Bacon loans? To what extent can these be mitigated?    Generally these types of loans called qualified mortgages and underwritten to Fannie guidelines are considered high quality.  We mitigate capital and illiquidity risk by maintaining excellent relationships with purchases of these types of loans   We already have an existing mortgage business so maintaining these relationships is core to our business as it is to other originators who will join the platform    What would happen if a borrower defaults on a loan? It would be great if you could walk through your procedure and its implications for Maker.    This is a standard process in mortgage.  If a borrower defaults (which servicers work to avoid) then the servicer forecloses on the house and then sells the asset.  Since the loan to value is generally low the result is cash back to the protocol which can be reinvested or stay in the pool.  The highest I have seen across residential loan types is just over 10% and a more average default rate is about 3%
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: Hi teej, Correct we are not proposing a “crypto-mortgage” the loan is only collateralized by a lien on the home recorded as an NFT on the blockchain and a lien at the county within which the house resides. Is your concern that we wouldn’t be able to originate enough volume to satisfy the appetite for the coin?  We have originated over $2 billion in loans to date and only a fraction are going to the protocol today.  Given we close loans in 24hrs and guarantee 15 days, yes we believe we are competitive with others and have the ability in the short run to generate approximately $200 million of assets to the protocol per month
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: karljacob:  loan is only collateralized by a lien on the home recorded as an NFT on the blockchain and a lien at the county within which the house resides.   I really like how it is an NFT on chain. That is the future !
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving positive feedback on proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: Thank you!  Our design goal was the smallest piece of the real world represented on chain.  Others have gone the route of wrapping the house in a NFT etc but we felt it was important to wrap something even smaller with less complexity.  The lien is generally just an address, lien amount and home value.  Its already recorded publicly so there is no downside to sharing it on chain and its stood the test of time in court.  Lots of potential down the road for what people can do with the NFTs…

3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: Smart contract risk is always a potential in any on-chain project as we’ve seen over the years. The risk for Bacon Protocol is lower than for most because the largest part of the assets are off-chain. It’s hard to use a Solidity exploit to steal a house . Bacon Protocol also recently completed and passed a second, independent audit as part of an always ongoing security effort. We also continue to be very thoughtful about keeping the complexity of the contracts low to reduce the risk surface area.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: It’s the future for sure. NFTs can be used to serve as notice of liens, encumbrances etc.
and sure beats a trip to the county to see what liens are on a property
Yea, a worldwide title company. Although, that doesn’t sound like a terrible idea lol
This is exciting, especially given the chops that LoanSnaps brings to the game. Let’s go !
Glad you are excited so are we!  We have originated over $2 Billion worth of loans already and sell to the government direct  We are ready
I am excited about this proposal and want to see more loan originators of this caliber.

@karljacob I took some time to familiarize with your product (listened to podcast, looked into history/details of LoanSnap). From what I can tell, you’ve radically under-sold the value proposition and opportunity in this signal request. In the attention economy, loudness wins. This is not a product that has been proposed to the DAO before (I think) and it seems to me that the combination of A) tokenized liens and B) potential scale of resi mortgage production is unique. Do you have a short video or write-up that more fully fleshes out the opportunity for the community Low engagement begets low engagement. @Recognized-Delegates please take a brief look at this—Richard Branson is in the equity. Few questions:  You are pitching a Maker-tailored D3M pool. What will the Bacon token emissions be for the pool? 3.5% as suggested on the Bacon website or higher at the quantum of a 5-10MM DAI pool? Looks like Total Value Locked is $7MM but Total Home Value is $44MM across 35 homes. From looking into the “eggs” section of the site, it does indeed look like Bacon is originating ultra low-LTV mortgages at the moment. What is the profile of borrower looking for such a low-leverage product? Are some of these shorter-term bridge loans for reno? Or are they all longer-term stabilized? Is LoanSnap selling off partial exposures to bHome holders or are these loans being originated afresh? In a regulatory capacity, how are you dealing with the yield-bearing nature of bHome? It is indeed LoanSnap the entity as opposed to a diffuse set of token holders, for example, that is doing the underwriting and driving the profit, right? Please synthesize your motivation for approaching MakerDAO into a few sentences.

content.content: karljacob:  The lien is generally just an address, lien amount and home value. Its already recorded publicly so there is no downside to sharing it on chain and its stood the test of time in court. Lots of potential down the road for what people can do with the NFTs…   I agree that the on-chain documenting of the lien is useful and the future. But can you confirm that, as purely a legal matter, the real world lien filed in the appropriate office is the only legally enforceable right. The NFT is a symbolic on-chain representation of that lien, but not binding against anyone else.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: In the protocol today, the servicer, who holds the lien on the county records, has the responsibility to bind the on-chain NFT with the lien. It’s more than purely symbolic and there are incentives for them to act as an agent. We see this as a way to bootstrap the future everyone knows is coming. It overcomes the large coordination problem before truly on-chain title is reality. There may be other steps along the path. Today, this setup is sufficient to ensure that the system works and is stable.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

None of the topics listed match

content.content: Totally agree on the value proposition here and need to bring attention to it. Where else do you suggest raising this to get the word out broader in Maker? A video is a cool idea. We’ll flesh out a more detailed writeup in the meantime. To answer your questions:   The 3.5% emission would be the base emission in bHOME, DAI or another USD equivalent returned from the underlying asset’s payments. The BACON (governance) emission would also go to the D3M pool and is much higher (52% currently) and could be at a negotiated rate for a large pool if agreed by our DAO.   We’ve been conservative on the lending side to start out. The protocol can push to 80% LTV in line with the FannieMae guidelines and some loans are towards that end. There’s a ton of pent up demand for people to unlock equity in their homes this year that we’re seeing and home values are up across the board. Some of the loans are second liens at higher rates. Most are first liens. None of these are bridge loans, hard money loans or other creative instruments. They are all long term loans underwritten to Fannie guidelines just like 99% of homeowners use to buy a house,   These are all freshly originated loans wholly owned by bHOME holders through the protocol.   LoanSnap is not driving the profit here making choices about what to include or not. FannieMae sets the standard terms and underwriting. The protocol (bHOME holders) purchase the loan through the logic in the smart contracts. Any originator can come and sell loans to the protocol once vetted and approved by the DAO. Mortgages are in a unique place in the ecosystem and the protocol has been through a lot of legal review by former SEC lawyers.   Two reasons: First, adding mortgages to MakerDAO as a key RWA that underpins a large part of the US financial system for years will help DAI to add scale and stability of MakerDAO. Second, it will add a key crypto-native asset to the Bacon Protocol so it can lend against more homes and get the crypto community more familiar and comfortable with an asset that’s not been on chain before.   We’ve been talking with various people at MakerDAO and in the RWA group about it off and on for two years and it’s always been clear there’s a huge benefit to both groups and it’s been a matter of getting the pieces in place on both sides.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

content.content: Yes from a legal perspective the lien is the only legally enforceable right  This is exactly how it is today for most mortgages that exist.

allanca:  In the protocol today, the servicer, who holds the lien on the county records, has the responsibility to bind the on-chain NFT with the lien. Does the NFT uniquely identify a given financial arrangement and can it confirm a strong chain of signatures between lender and borrower? Please provide any supporting documentation that’s available. Also, how do you plan on navigating the current consumer debt that’s piled above 15-trillion dollars in the US and the prospects that mortgage defaults related to too much credit, are right around the corner?     teej:  Richard Branson is in the equity. content.content: Why would there need to be a machine verifiable chain of digital signatures or Ricardian Contract to make this work? The US based homes have liens owned by the protocol and are verifiable by anyone on the county records. There’s some need to trust in the Servicer to do that right and uphold it. You’d have to have that trust as well with any signature chain proposal or contract hash. In this case, the first Servicer has done tens of thousands of these and is held to high standards for billions of dollars worth of loans by much bigger investors than MakerDAO. Mortgages are collateralized by houses. It’s the first bill almost everyone pays. If they default, there’s lots of home value to liquidate to make the protocol whole. The loans in the protocol today are at 33% combined LTV on the homes. Even in the worst housing situation in 100 years, in 2008, the max default rate on much, much lower quality lending was around 10% which was all recoverable. Compare that to all the other risks DAI already takes on and it looks pretty good

content.content: allanca:  Why would there need to be a machine verifiable chain of digital signatures or Ricardian Contract to make this work? The US based homes have liens owned by the protocol and are verifiable by anyone on the county records. There’s some need to trust in the Servicer to do that right and uphold it. You’d have to have that trust as well with any signature chain proposal or contract hash.   Got it. So, essentially you guys are offering something similar to Mortgage-back securities via an an erc-token (maybe erc777,) a.k.a. as an NFT to Retail, and they just have to trust that you’ll do the right thing, correct? If there is an off-chain liquidation, how is it reflected on-chain? And was your platform a Compound fork, like are you using the cToken functions to calculated interest rate and PAY NFT owners? Also, who’s the Custodian of the NFTs, the borrowers or you guys?

content.content: Great questions. There is an LP token, bHOME. ERC-20. Off-chain liquidations are foreclosures handled normally. The proceeds are passed back on chain. Not a direct Compound fork. But, yes, the protocol has an AMM that decides the rate based on supply and demand. The Bacon Protocol contract is the custodian of the NFTs. When a borrower comes to the protocol, an originator vets the house and the borrower to Bacon Protocol/Fannie Mae standards, sets the lien, and mints the NFT. The NFT can then be staked in the smart contract in exchange for a loan up to the lien amount.The loans and NFT liens back the bHOME (ERC-20) token. There is some trust required of the servicers/originators. They are licensed and regulated heavily by the states and have originated and serviced billions of $ in loans before. Over time, the protocol will become more decentralized and trustless. In order to get the growth in DAI through RWA we all want, there will have to be some trust placed outside the blockchain.

content.content: Bumping this Signal Request since it ends tomorrow and we only have fourteen non-abstain votes.

Hi @abdalla, I’d like to share some information with you about the Collateral Onboarding process. There is a guide to help collateral applicants move through the process. I’m happy to answer any questions when you take a look at it. When onboarding collateral, the process is best started with a MIP6. One post which is good to read are the Guidelines for Onboarding. This allows the collateral applicant to self assess on if your collateral would be a good candidate for Maker. Right now, this doesn’t appear to be the case and we would be unable to prioritize your collateral at this time. Also, I would highly encourage you to talk first about the actual collateral you would like to onboard and the business opportunity and investment with the Maker protocol. I see many questions replying to your post that are focused on that. The questions in the MIP6 application template will help guide you in this process. D3M is a collateral technology that is undergoing an evolution and it’s unknown at this time whether it would be a fit for your collateral. It’s best not to focus on a specific technology as the basis of a collateral application. The business opportunity is what is important early in the collateral onboarding process.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: It would be nice to see more engagement on the merits of tokenizing mortgage loans on the blockchain from @Tosh9.0,  @mrabino1, @flipflopflapdelegate, or @Saludiego_201. As far as yield farms and liquidity are concerned, the agency RMBS market is the safest and highly liquid. This could also unlock trillions of dollars in liquidity trapped in the form of home equity thereby increasing the velocity of money and benefitting everyone in the process. Bacon’s fundamental value proposition is the disintermediation of mortgage loan origination by leveraging its relationship with LoanSnap to scale the onboarding of mortgage-backed NFTs. Imagine that you are a mortgage loan originator, why would you go the TradFi route that takes weeks to close whereas the DeFi route takes hours? Also, they have changed their bHome to a 1:1 pegged stablecoin. This can also be onboarded as an RWA once there is sufficient supply/demand.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Thanks for sharing that, @monkey.irish. I wasn’t aware of that and will go through the MIP6-process depending on this vote.

Please keep in mind, even if the poll is successful, the information needed above still applies. The Signal Request followed by a successful onchain poll signals an “investigate implementation” by the community.  If that happens, we’ll be back where we started as I will request the same information from you. This is why following the collateral onboarding process is the quickest way to determine, for both the collateral applicant and Maker, if a collateral is appropriate and makes sense to onboard. The longer we wait to get the necessary information, the more time we both spend on this and it typically leads to frustration on one or both sides. The process is designed to minimize this. Start with the Guidelines for onboarding. If it’s not clear that these parameters can be met, it’s best to wait until you can. Otherwise, it will be the first thing the collateral stakeholders will look at if the onchain poll passes and if it’s not clear to us, we’ll inform you that we are unable to prioritize your collateral at this time. We don’t need to run through the entire process to determine this and it can be done by the collateral applicant. Part of the Collateral Engineering Service’s role is to help educate applicants on the process the collateral stakeholders follow. While there are other ways to engage with the community (like the Signal Request), these just extend the timeframe. The onboarding process is design to reduce the work on both sides. Keep in mind, there needs to be a clear business case for Maker to onboard collateral. The guidelines and collateral application template help us understand that. Let me know if you have any questions. There are a lot of details in the process and we can help you understand them.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

(I don’t have the recording link—but should be on the MKR YouTube channel). And if you still think it’s doable, after listening to the words of wisdom with regards to the D3M, I got an ice cold Igloo to sell you in Tijuana, Mexico. LMK, while supplies lasts

content.content: Yesterday’s explanation of D3M risks was illuminating, for sure. Here’s why I’m staying with yes: 1.) The SR doesn’t specify the desired Debt Ceiling, so Maker Governance can choose how much of this D3M it wants to onboard. If the total D3M risk is deemed too high, I’d love to see it reduced elsewhere. Aave seemed of particular concern, given the recent UST and ChainLink debacle. 2.) MKR circulating market capitalization is $1,38bn today. If we take that as a measure of the size of the operation, I believe Maker should focus on growth, and aggressively so. Growth means opening new lines of business, which entails taking on additional risk. Should this risk be mitigated? Yes, definitely so. Yesterday’s call surfaced a couple of good ways to do so. For instance: collateralization of D3M lines or insurances. 3.) We have seen competition from FRAX, Cytus, and others make massive progress in RWA, even though Maker probably has the best process and clearest thinking in that space. Real-world exposure and integration will drive the whole space forward, in my opinion. Why should anyone care about a blockchain native token, when there are so precious little uses outside of a tiny bubble. I talked to John Nahas of Avalanche last week, and he said something that really stuck with me: "The blockchain space is fighting about crumbs when the kitchen is right next door!" We need to open that door, and we shouldn’t be too picky about where the door handle is. I deeply appreciate Maker’s concern with risk and making the best possible stablecoin. But it needs to find ways to grow aggressively. So either Maker spins out MetaDAOs that can run experiments and fail without damage to the mothership, or it experiments itself and mitigates risk along the way. Not experimenting is not a viable option in my mind. The signal request is turning out No, as it stands. So my points may be mute. I hope they make sense, though. Now, about that Igloo…
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: There have been several places in this post where we talk about experimentation. It’s an interesting topic since I’ve dealt with this my entire career in product development. I like to look at this as architectural runway or innovation work as it relates to engineering. Most engineering teams run in some sort of iterative fashion. CES has a two week sprint cycle. When we plan the work for a sprint, we pull in the most valuable collateral work for the protocol based upon community and stakeholder feedback. This is the collateral work that enables us to pay the bills and “keep the lights on.” We also look at the architecture or innovation work and see if it makes sense to pull any of that in for the current sprint. Right now, we have four D3M scenarios (Aave, Compound, Maple, TrueFi), each with a different set of parameters we are investigating. I realize Aave is onboarded but we’ve learned some things so we need to factor that into the other three collaterals using the D3M technology. In addition, we have the institutional vault work with Antalpha. That will be the first one we attempt to onboard. I’m sharing all this as an instructive example and to talk about relative priorities. Finite resources are a constant so it’s imperative we only work on the highest value and/or strategic collateral. Not only do we have CES but the Risk, Oracles, Protocol Engineering, Legal, and RWF core units involved with collateral onboarding. When we experiment, we could be taking time from one or more of these core units so we need to be clear on the business opportunity and understand the alignment to strategic objectives. Notice I said nothing about technology.  As it relates to this SR, @ejbarraza my suggestion is to ideate with the community and develop the business opportunity so you can help us understand specifically how it will meet and exceed the Guidelines for Onboarding (we are looking for growth). We’re all super busy so the more complete something is the quicker Maker can decide if it’s something we want to invest in. As a side note, we have an entire core unit, Growth, dedicated to business development and they could give you some constructive feedback on your project. Their public channel is on the MakerDAO Discord server. Once the opportunity development is complete then consider posting a MIP6 on the forum. I appreciate your excitement in working with Maker and like what you are trying to offer. If you have any questions on the collateral onboarding process, we are happy to help answer questions.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: This topic was automatically closed 30 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
